description.text:
Earphone wire organiser specifically designed for smartphone earphones that has a long hard piece for volume and answer call button.

However, the design is generic enough to cater to any model of earbud wires. May need to adjust the size of the side slots according to the diameter of your wire.

Autodesk Fusion 360 *.f3d file is also provided for those who wanted to customise or modify its characteristics.

I will add another thing of similar design, but with cloth and catch strap later.

Printer:

3dison

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

100

Notes:

Works best with more elastic element. Tested with PLA only. Print with translucent PLA looks better than e.g. solid black PLA.

You can print with 0.1 mm resolution for a nicer looking print.

There are 3 holes on the sides of the thing to secure the entire earbud wire.
Top of the thing has two holes; one hole on each side.
Bottom of the thing has one hole on the left side.
There are two grooves running from top to bottom in the middle.

If you are using earphones with volume/call control, lay the control section on the right groove. Top two holes are to hold earbuds firmly. Wind the earbud sections until you can slide the wire of each earbud into those two holes. Do no slide the wires in yet,

Wind the jack section around the left groove.
Secure the jack by sliding the wire into the slot on the bottom.

Now secure the earbuds by sliding each wire into the top holes.
This will allow you to free small sections of the earbuds and jack wires without unwinding the whole piece.

If you are using earphones without anything control section, you can wind it any way you like.

Secure the whole bundle by wrapping the strap over the top, around the whole thing.
There is a 'hooked' catch at the end of the strap.
Push the catch into the nearer hole.

To release the catch, press against the strap on the left of the catch. Then push/slide the catch to left.

title: Prosthetic Hand Attachment : I Phone Holder

description.text:
Hello all!
My name is Rachel Thompson and I'm an engineering major at Seattle Pacific University. I designed, modeled and 3D printed this "thing". It's a prosthetic hand attachment which allows amputees to hold a cell phone with their prosthetic hand (designed by SPU). My design has two main parts, the bottom piece which anchors into the prosthetic hand and two elongated arms which slide into the other part- the top piece. Together the two pieces can hold a cell phone with the aid of a rubber band which is attached to the hooks on the back sides of both pieces (as shown above in the photos). The rubber band creates the tension required to hold the phone in place in the mechanism. The design is simple and easy to print, just download my files and print the top and bottom separately and you're good to go! IMPORTANT DISCLAIMER: the photos of my print are of version 1.0, and the files are for version 2.0, so when you print, it will look slightly different, but no need to worry! Version 2.0 is new and improved! Also FYI this model is sized for I phone 6 and 6 plus, but it can easily be re-sized to fit larger phones and tablets as well! Enjoy, and happy printing!

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Up to you! (Mine was low..)

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed with black 1.75mm PLA at 205 degrees Fahrenheit, I found printing at exactly 205 was very helpful in printing quality prints!

I printed with a very small printer, so it made it difficult to print the entire length of the arms on the BOTTOM piece, so I recommend using a larger printer, or changing the deminsions of the arms to your liking.

title: Monoprice Wanhao Maker Select i3v2 Spring Cups

description.text:
None of the cups on thingiverse fit my springs. not sure if mine are different from the wanhao ones?? they were all too small (by a lot)

so I made my own. I had to print them at 103% (on x and y only leave z at 100%) They NEED to fit LOOSE and not restrict the springs or they will inhibit them from "rising" on fine adjustments. so clean up the inside also if your printer is a little sloppy.

These will keep the springs from "tilting and bending" which will throw off your bed level.

I made them 7.3mm tall which is a little smaller than the spring fully compressed so they won't interfere with the movement or compression of the spring as long as they fit LOOSELY.

both holes are also beveled though you won't really see this unless you print at high resolution.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select i3v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm or better

Infill:

100%

Notes:

infill is 100% but its small enough that I don't think infill settings will matter.

Make sure the spring is a clean loose fit. no wiggle but also no resistance. use a knife to clean the inside wall up as well. put the spring in and compress several times make sure no resistance. Your ready to go. going 104% might remove the need to clean up. just make sure you change both x and y equally and do NOT change z 7.3mm is the highest you can go without interfering with the ability of the spring to compress fully.

I just went into tinkercad and started making cylinders (I imported my own custom cylinder from 3ds max to bypass the low polygon nature of parts made IN tinkercad.

I use a parabolic cone to make the bevels.

the hardest part was the calculations to place the parts relative to each other before cutting. there is no "center" option in tinkercad :-)

title: InductriksMaxi, - Inductrix inspired micro FPV Quad trainer

description.text:
This is a micro quad (113mm diagonal) inspired by Blade Inductrix model. Perfect for beginners, it can take quite a hit before the damage will be unrecoverable. Small cracks can be cured with a drop of acetone (ABS) or CA... with a 2:1 power-ratio it can be quite fast and agile. I did it to learn the Rate mode FPV flying, since learning with a heavier quad can be dangerous and expensive :). And it is easy to carry it with you all the time.

Parts used:

  • Blade NanoQX FPV board (mounted below the frame, with stock foam adhesive placed on the top of the board, two drops of hot glue do it too, the FPV version has stronger FETs which is necessary to handle the bigger motors)
  • 8.5mm Motors from micro-motor-warehouse.com
  • Turnigy 1S 600mAh
  • Hubsan X4 Props
  • Quanum FPV cam

All up weight came up to be 71g. Frame alone is 21g. Flying times are anywhere between 5-7 minutes, depending on your style.
UPDATE#1:
I have increased the thickness of motor pods beams, since these have proved to be the weakest spot in the design. No measurable increase in weight :).
Successfully crashed the frame several times with absolutely no damage.

Printer:

MaxiKossel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm - 0.3mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

ABS, 2 Perimeters (shells)
Prints with lots of support, so make sure to tune the settings for easy separation.
Other that that it is an easy print...
Antenna Saver is optional and can be glued with CA or Acetone, if printed in ABS

I have been flying the Blade Inductrix for quite some time now... I really like the concept of not hitting things with quad propellers, especially during the learning curve :).
Blade Inductrix is fine for indoors and calm outside days, but in my opinion it lacks power for FPV applications. And although there are quite some conversions for FPV, I feel like the stock 6mm motors are at their limit if they have to carry the additional weight of even a tiny FPV cam.

So the InductixMaxi was born.

I really do not get why other people didn't do it earlier :). OK, most of those who can fly micro quads do not need propeller protection anymore, but I am still learning...
Besides, flying (and crashing) a 250 quad can be expensive, and dangerous. This thing is perfect for beginners, well to my opinion it is.
After practice with this thing I feel more confident to fly my 250-sized copter!

remixed_from.title: Smooth X-axis for Prusa i3 with Leadscrews

description.text:
I have redesign the belt tensioner and its idler to suit 625zz bearing and longer 8mm rods which come with Zonestar prusa. I also added some holes in motor mount and idler to fix the rods better via nuts. X-carriage is from Prusa rework package, I have not modified it.

Be aware! This kit uses standard distance between rods, Zonestar distance is ~1mm smaller. This means that you will have to drill some extra holes in the metal plate to mount Zonestar carriage onto standard prusa carriage or use some direct-drive adapters.

title: Tool Holder for Prosthetic Hands
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is an expandable tool holder that is attachable to the prosthetic SPU Engineering Falcon Hand. This tool allows users to use the object by securely hold its handle, but it requires the other hand to operate it. The tool holder assembly is made out of 5 parts: hexagonal attachment (x1), base (x1), female part (x1), male part (x2). The hexagonal attachment is press-fit on the base, other parts are slide fit to each other. With the aid of the velcro straps, users can easily adjust the opening of the tool corresponding to the size of the object's handle, and then tighten it. Rubber sheets are glued on the four corners of the tool holder for extra gripping area and resistance to twisting movements of the object when it sits inside the tool.

To recharge a mechanical watch

The design was done for a competition at our local maker space - (http://www.binaryspace.co.za/). The competition was divided into 2 challenges:

Challenge Part 1:
Design a single sided pcb that functions as a clock.

Challenge Part 2:
Design a 3d printed enclosure for a 10cm in diameter clock pcb.

This clock was designed by me, and inspired by the Disneyland castles. It has space for a 10cm round clock face and all batteries, electronics and clock mechanisms are housed inside the square body of the castle.

For my build, I also put small pictures of shadows of the Disney characters in the windows, and they are lit with high bright LED's so it doubles as a nightlight.

The whole project was 3D printed and spray painted afterwards. I also included a pdf with the design I created and etched on the pcb for the clock face.

My husband also created an entry: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1586350

print_settings.Notes:: Most of this model will print ok with a "normal" sized nozzle but will lose the rivet details.  It is designed for a 250 micron (or smaller) nozzle with the walkway demanding an extrusion width of 250 microns.  You can force a larger nozzle to small extrusion widths but the quality will degrade the further you push.

title: Another N-Scale Railroad Bridge - Plate Girder

description.text:
This is my second design specifically for an N-Scale (or 1:160) model. This one is of a Plate and Girder style of bridge. This design can be printed with a normal nozzle but at the expense of losing all the nice rivets. It can also be printed with a solid roadbed and a pedestrian walkway though that option does require a small nozzle.

Here is an instructable coming covering assembly:

http://www.instructables.com/id/Building-a-1160-N-Scale-Model-of-a-Plate-Girder-Ra

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

All models, source and STLs, are saved in full scale and need to be factored down to N-Scale! This means downsizing by/to 0.625. I model in full scale because Sketchup Pro solid functions seem to get confused by tiny little things.

Most of this model will print ok with a "normal" sized nozzle but will lose the rivet details. It is designed for a 250 micron (or smaller) nozzle with the walkway demanding an extrusion width of 250 microns. You can force a larger nozzle to small extrusion widths but the quality will degrade the further you push.

80mm version is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1579798
120mm version is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1581974

30, 50 and 92 mm versions will also come.

author: KarinaPGeraldo

description.text:
A simple three tiered shooting target for Nerf. An easy guide to get started with FreeCAD design and 3D printing.

-

About the target :

Shoot the centre of the target to knock down all three rings.
Shoot the middle target ring to knock down the outer two rings.
Shoot the outer target ring to knock down only the outer ring.

Getting started with FreeCAD – Objects

A great feature of FreeCAD is working with solid 3D parts.
Use the 'Part' Workbench. ('Workbench' is essentially a set of tools to show in the toolbar area)

Part Workbench selection

Create a 3D cylinder object and place it in 3D space. The example below is a small coin like cylinder.

Copy and paste the same cylinder or create a new one at the same placement. Then change the radius to be smaller by the amount we want the target rim edges to be. In our example its a tiny 0.2mm so the radius (half diameter) is 1.8mm. Then we position this cylinder back by 0.2mm ready to cut away leaving the sides and face.

Select the larger of the two cylinders first then shift select the smaller cylinder we want to remove from the larger one. From the Part menu select 'Boolean' > 'Cut'

This should provide a cut out cap like object.

If you look inside the 'Cut' Object in the 'Model' panel you will notice the original objects (cylinders) are simply children of this new cut object. You can adjust the smaller cylinders placement and see the results. (just remember when editing children that visual results do not show up instantly and you have to press enter or change input focus to trigger a render).
Have a play.

Using these cut techniques you can generate the full face of each target piece. Notice that by making a larger face and removing the center by 'cutting' a cylinder from our original 'Cut' object we end up with a more complex shape. You can 'Cut' Cuts, intersects, unions and fusions over and over where you need to.
Shown below we use 'Union' to combine the smaller and larger faces of a target piece.

We can then use a simple Cube object to create a cut in the face for the pivot (holder) for this target face.

The resulting cut will allow us to build an arm to hold up the face and pivot from the base.
We will create a shaft that is a shape a bit like house guttering facing open towards the face front.
You can use the techniques as described in previous steps just using Cubes instead of cylinders to create the arm your own way.

Once you have your arm built you should be feeling confident in using the boolean techniques to build up simple objects.

We will want to add the little feet that prop up the face when used on a pivot.
They are just little rectangles sticking out from the arm near the base, but allowing some height above the base for rotation (we don't build the base in this tutorial - but you can see it'a a simple cone with a hinge/toothpick cylinder hole).

Your little foot added to the arm should do the trick. However, maybe you want the target to be harder to knock down or you find the balance not quite right. we may need to adjust the angle of the feet.
The angles in FreeCAD are set per object and by axis. Simply put, 90 degrees on the correct axis would be like moving a clock hand from 12 to 3. For a simple calculation like this we would need to assign the axis to only 'x' (as example) so the axis might read X:1, Y:0, Z:0. Then we simply put 90 in the degrees input field.
You can play with the axis and see what you get, X:1, Y:1, Z:0 would split the rotation across both the x and y axis so 45 degrees to each.
If rotations get hard to visualise, you can use a simple trick to do one axis at a time and copy/paste the object then use 'Union' to create a new object which has a fresh 0 degrees starting point then apply your next axis rotation. (it's not very efficient but fine for small projects)

Once your foot is placed and angled to your satisfaction you can create a mirror.
A mirrored object just mirrors along a chosen axis/plane.

We want our foot below to be one on both sides of the arm. We use the Mirroring option from the part menu.

In our example we want to mirror along the YZ plane.

The result is a quick duplication of the foot on the other side of our model.

The other parts are easily created using the techniques above.
Have a play around and you will be able to change and improve upon this design :)

description.text:
The rework X-carriage is a requirement for a number of different extruder and hot end mounts but I was unable to find it in .scad (OpenSCAD) format which meant that customising it to add self levelling or to modify it to suit different X axis configurations was a bit of a kludge.

This is an OpenSCAD version of the x-carriage that will, hopefully, be of some use to others who want to customise the design.

V1.0.1 of the file includes a number of minor changes to match the original design more closely with a deeper belt clamp and a deeper bearing offset. It also includes a new setting for the end stop trigger.

The current version of the file supports two different bearing configurations - a twin bearing per axle setup as per the original design and a single bearing per axle design which I customised for my own Geetech Prusa i3 to use the original bearings.

I have also added an optional cutout, again aimed at Geetech users, which clears the X tensioner bearing bolt ensuring you get maximum x travel. This may be of use on other Prusa i3 machines too.

There is also an optional square corner option, added to suit my Geetech Prusa i3 that helps with x end stop activation. It may well be useful for other Prusa printers too where the end stop switch is near the top of the carriage.

There are switches at the top of the file to change bearings per axle (1 or 2) and if the design should include the tensioner bearing cutout. The default values mimic the original rework design.

All other values have parameters at the top of the source so pretty much everything can be easily customised if you know what you are doing.

I hope you enjoy my first contribution to the community ! If you use it or like it, please let me know and I'll add some of the other rework items in .scad files as I create them.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:114745

comments.text: Thanks for posting this design!  I had to Install Open SCAD on my Linux Mint system to allow me to generate the Geeetech Prusa I3 Pro B version with double bearings.  (I use FreeCAD normally.) Your instructions to generate the modifications; tensioner cut out and end stop actuator were  fairly simple to follow. I've ordered a set of Drylin LM8UU 25mm substitute bearings in place of the LM8LUU ones (Wonder why they don't do 45mm ones?) which should arrive within the next week. This looks like the ideal solution to fit them!
comments.author: Soadyheid

comments.text: Great work. Thanks a lot!
comments.author: patriciorivera

comments.text: Thanks for publishing this and including your OpenScad source! Can you please credit ch1t0's version (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:114745) as your source since that's where eMotion-Tech got it from but didn't provide proper source credits.
comments.author: grokbeer

remixed_from.title: PG35L Micro Extruder V5 - For J-Head

title: Dual Micro Extruder based on V5 from ultibots

description.text:
This is a set of modified micro extruders with a mount plate. This spaces the j-heads 20mm apart, and will attach to the standard spacing of jonas kuehlings x carriage. It is a work in progress and i have not printed it yet. It should work, but i make no guarantees. Solidworks parts/assemblies are included and the stls haven't been checked or cleaned up yet. I would rotate flip the mirror extruder part if you are printing it. I would also rotate the mount plate by 90 degrees. Update 10/10/2013:
I changed the mounting configuration for the extruders. So the the extruder bodies and mount plate have changed. I updated the solidworks files(which are now in one zip file), the extruder bodies and the mounting plate.

parts required should be: 4x m3x25 or m3x30(this one will need some extra washers) shcs to attach the motors.
4x m3 nuts to accatch motors
6x m4x20 flat head to attach bearings like mcmaster part # 91294A196
6x m4 nut to attach bearings
4x m3x18 shcs to attach extruders to mounting plate
4x m3 nut to attach extruder to mounting plate
2 m4 x 15 (roughly) to attach dual extruder assembly to carriage
2 m4 nuts to attach extruder assembly to carriage
4x m3x30 shcs for idler. (could go longer if you want it spring loaded.)
4x m3 nuts for the idler 6x 624 bearings
2x pg35l mottors
2x hobbed gear things
2x heatsinks
2x 4mm fans you will also need to print two of the pg35 fan ducts frond here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39135

title: Copy of Ghostbusters-TRS-80 Pocket Interface, PC4 Holder

description.text:
The Radio Shack PC-4 was used in the first movie, primarily by Dr. Spengler in the first half. It can be seen after the library scene, and during the Ghostbusters commercial. The Calculator was originally made by Casio, but, in 1983 Radio Shack and Tandy both made versions of it. (Information provided by the Vintage Calculators Forum: //www.xnumber.com/vintage_calc/)

In the film, it was mated with a TRS-80 Cassette Interface. Part Number: 26-3650.
TRS-80 Cassette Interface
The TRS-80 Cassette Interface was combined with the Radio Shack PC-4 calculator for a few scenes in the first movie. The Interface provided a means of data storage between the PC-4 model calculator and a tape recorder. Programs could also be loaded via the interface from software tapes available at that time.

based off of Part Number: 26-3651.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hJHPApPzQRc

title: Sega Dreamcast GD-EMU SD Card Tray
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you'd like to order one of these printed. They are available through my website: https://bit-district.com/gd-emu-sd-card-tray.html

The GD-EMU is an SD card adapter that replace the ever failing GD-ROM drives in Sega Dreamcast consoles. These are great devices but they leave a very large space open inside the console meaning you can easily, accidentally drop your SD card inside the console and be forced to disassemble it to get the card back. These files are to print a tray or finisher pieces that wall off the insides of the console making it not just more professional looking and visually pleasing but also making it impossible to lose a card inside the console. This also makes it easier to insert and remove cards and there are optional spaces provided for additional card storage; making it more versatile as well.

This SD card Tray comes in two pieces. The base bolts to the console in place of the GD-ROM drive and supports the GD-EMU. The shield is press-fit into the lid to finish enclosing off the area making it impossible to drop your SD card inside through an open lid.

There are three different STL files for the base, one includes a set of 4 slots on the left to allow you to store additional SD cards (the slots are staggered to allow easier gripping), another with 5 SD card slots on the right (these are not staggered).. and the third file with no card slots is simply for people who are not interested in this feature.

If you have an old version 5.0 or older GDMU (without any screw holes) then use the "_for_old_rev_gdemu" files. If you have version 5.1 or newer GDEMU Then use the file without that suffix. I believe fitment should work on all Dreamcasts, however if you use this file I would appreciate a comment confirming fitment.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Supports are necessary when printing the shield, they are not necessary for the base. You can get away with low- infill (I used 20%) since the part doesn't need to really support much weight. The walls are all 2mm thick so keep that in mind when deciding the number of perimeters based on your nozzle size.

Parts Required

Installation is very simple and requires a Philips screwdriver as well as the 3 screws that originally held down your GD-ROM drive in addition to the long screw included with the GD-EMU.

Step 1: With the Dreamcast opened and the GD-ROM removed place the base part as shown and bolt it down using one of the original GD-ROM screws. This should be snug but not too tight. Step 2: Remove the stand-offs from the GD-EMU then plug it into the Dreamcast. use screws from the original GD-ROM drive in the two upper holes to affix the GD-EMU to the base part. Then use the long screw included with the GD-EMU (without the spacer) in the lower left screw hole. Again, these should be snug but not too tight. Step 3: insert the shield part into the upper Dreamcast case aligning the circular nub with the matching indent on the sheld. This should fit tightly such that the sheld will stay in place. Step 4: open the lid on the dreamcastand lower the upper case half directly down onto the lower half making sure everything lines up. Once back together you can re-install the bolts that hold the Dreamcast case together.

description.text:
The Cable Eater is a must have to reduce the lenght of a long cable that runs off your desk and tends to be crushed by the wheels of your desk chair...

I designed so i can keep my headset wire safe (2 meters long and 3mm thick), and thanks to it, I transformed my 2m long wire into a 30cm long !

Lenght gain : up to 99% with a standard 3mm wire !

Comment if you want other cable size standards :)

Standard version diameter 10cm. Small version 7cm.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.2

Infill:

75%-100%

Notes:

Working with PLA, but ABS with its flexibility might be easier to assemble (didn't tried yet).

As there are some snap-fit parts, I would recommend to print at low speed (40mm/s and 25mm/s for small perimeters).

For a smooth finish prefer 0.1mm layer height, but 0.2mm will do just fine.

About the infill : As the A and C parts are pretty flat and large, you may want to keep a high density (75-100%).
However B part infill can be reduced to 50%, but keep in mind that this piece will need to be strong and a bit flexible (mine was printed at 100% PLA, it's quite strong but not very flexible).

Heated bed is recommended for PLA to avoid wrapping issues.

Printing time (0.1mm - 40mm/s - 75%) :
A part : 2h30
B part : 15min
C part : 2h15

Step 1

Take the A part, and put your cable in the center

Step 2

Block your cable using part B, snap-fitting it on the A part pivots.

Step 3

Snap-fit part C pivot to the part B center hole.

/!\ Make sure your cable is passing between the 4 little 'teeth' of part C /!\

Step 4

Rollup your cable by holding Part C in one hand (part C should face the ground), while turning Part A CLOCKWISE (turning the other way might damage your cable) till the desired lenght !

To unroll your cable, do not turn the parts, it's not necessary. Just hold the 2 strands with both hands, and pull.

3D Print snap-fits

Snap-fit parts was a bit challenging to achieve...

I first designed vertical clipping parts (Lego brick system) but the inside pressure generated by the cable being coiled was enough to disassemble the model.

I then tried to design snap-fits based on Eiki Martinson and Jon Lusk's research (http://eikimartinson.com/engineering/3dparts/pivot1-m.jpg). But didn't managed to print it well (and strong enough) with PLA. As I wanted an easy printable model, I decided to look for something else.

Finally, I solved my problem while sleeping (as often) and came out with a simple horizontal snap-fit design (part B). Easy to print, reliable, strong (I hope in long term), and quite easy to assemble.

If you try to design and print snap-fits, keep in mind that FDM technology has limitations regarding both raw materials (quality, strenght, flexibility) and precision, even if we tend to prefer thinking that it's revolutionnary and limitless !

This is the Universal Tweeter Pod.
This was designed so it could be mounted either on the dash board of a vehicle or mounted on the A pillar.
You can mount with a 3mm screw so it can be rotated for optimum tweeter positioning or simply use 3M tape to attach it.
there is a slot in the back of the foot so speaker cable may be passed through the base of the foot or it can be passed directly through the sole of the foot depending on how you wish to mount it.
There is enough room in the rear of the pod so you can leave some slack in the speaker cable to make wiring the tweeter easier, once wired the tweeter can be simply pushed into the pod without too much bunching of the cable.

This mounts perfectly on the existing dash speaker grill in an Audi A4 B8K
giving you the ability to create a very high end 3 way speaker setup

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

5%

Notes:

4 Top layers
4 Bottom Layers
3 outer Layers
printer on Glass with ABS
(remember it gets hot on the dash !) ABS or PETG will be best.

This was a 3 hour print with reasonable support added.
Support needs to be fine so edges of the foot are crisp and welded together.

Printing

Best to print this on it's face, you will need to rotate it forward 115 deg.
support is required! so it doesn't sag internally on the roof and supports the foot.
In the picture a Hybrid Audio Legatia VI Special Edition Pro 1 tweeter is installed.
A blank STL has also been supplied so you can cut out the desired hole to suit your tweeter.

Software Used

Designed in Solidworks
Printed with Simplify 3D 0.20 height, infill, no raft - on glass - ABS
Linguette posteriori per portafoto.
Vaso conico

Gen7 case

This is a Gen7 board case based on Brazilian version but not limited to. It should works on any Gen7 board.
Sketchup source available for download, but I can do modifications by request, just let me know.
Cooling: The fan mount is positioned directly on top of the motor drivers and the windows are located only on walls to enable a distributed airflow along the board.

• Distance between the holes: 119mm and 95mm (outer border)
  • Board max size: 135mm x 111mm
  • Internal height: 32mm
  • External volume: 150mm x 116mm x 38mm
  • Fan size: 40mm x 40mm
• Lid STL updated: The size was incorrect, different from the base.
• Added an alternative fan mount on the box right side.

Optimized for ABS. The box is composed by 6 parts, where:
  • 1 base
  • 4 walls (left, right, top, bottom)
  • 1 lid
    • Take care with the first layer height 'cause that will be the box external surface. You just need to print one of each and assemble it using glue (super glue, acetone, etc) Its recommended a 40mm x 20mm Fan for best cooling performance. New optional side FAN mount. STL files prefixed by SIDE_FAN.
    Print one of each and glue the "fan_interface" on "right" piece.

description.text:
Have you ever troubles trying to imaging how a surface looks like? With OpenSCAD and 3D printer it is easy! You can write an equation z=f(x,y), print the result and actually feel the surface. Sample stl-files are for the equations:
z(x,y)=-.015(xx+yy);
z(x,y)=3(sin(10x) +sin(10y));
z(x,y)=.01(x+y)(x+y);
z(x,y)=.001xxx+.02y*y;
You you can use the file as a library for you model.

More from Math

description.text:
A mostly 3D printed and PVC pipe supported crossbow.
The design is based on a classical medieval crossbow and adapted to be printed.
This is a proof of concept design and a proof of concept to be pinned to the wall.

Additional requirements:

  • 3* 400x20mm light grey PVC pipe for 10bar (for the support)
  • 1* about 800x20mm dark grey PVC pipe for 16bar (for the bow)
  • a few cm of 2.85mm filament or metal pins

To create the bow, search the internet for "PVC Archery".

Please be aware, this is a toy and must not be used for real shooting. You may harm yourself and maybe others.

It requires a long print time caused by the high infill. It took multiple days for me to print it!

Updates 1:

  • Added a PipeGuideFix-v2 as smaller version to simplify bow connection
  • Added a Rubberband-Fix to be glued on. It holds the rubberband to pull the trigger forward. This was done to change the rubber band without disassembling. Push the rubber band through the hole and insert a 30mm piece of filament to hold it in place.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm nozzle @0.1mm layers

Infill:

high!

Notes:

Only the trigger and maybe the trigger roll needs support. There are two versions available (one with support and one without).

For the BotGuide as well as for the TopGuideShort, there are also slightly longer and shorter versions to deal with PVC-Pipe length issues.

Also multiple versions of the bow clip are available to fit different sizes of bows.

All other objects an be rotated to be printed with a maximum overhang of 45° or small bridges smaller than 1cm.
Glue all connections to provide more stability.

description.text:
This is a Remix of an item that someone I believe got from a another artist, but I can't find his/her information. I do not take credit for this model, just sharing it in a printable format. Upright printing is especially tough on a printer where the bed moves in Y, as you get a lot of wobble once you're getting toward the top.

I had a lot of bad luck trying to print the original version of this, so I re-oriented everything and separated the parts. This way you can fill your own build plate with multiple parts. These parts have also been oriented for best printing. Supports will still be needed for some pieces though. It seems this original model was made in Blender or something very fluid, because the models have some odd artifacts when viewing them. Some of this shows in the final print, as you can see from my pictures, but nothing terrible. Just be aware if you're a perfectionist :-).

Printer:

I had to do 6 top layers (at 0.1mm) to get a clean top for the white sides. Also, silver pieces DO NOT need support, but Red_Middle and white sides were printed with supports. The Red_Middle appears to touch the bed in all places at first glance, but doesn't really. So supports are needed.

title: Delta Kossel ZProbe Optical Endstop Flag

description.text:
An optical endstop flag for the Nylon "Delta Kossel Fisheye Effector with Adjust balance Levelling Hammock" commonly available on Aliexpress.

While this effort boasts "autolevel", there is no obvious way (or instructions on how) to attach either an optical or mechanical endstop switch.

Thankfully, rwubbels has shared his "Kossel effector autoleveling with optical switch"
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1191506
a simple standoff to attach an optical autolevel sensor, however while he used a bent piece of wire as the trigger, I wanted something more "flag-like" as I found that the wire would trigger initially - but would disengage if pushed past the effective sensor area.

This is a very simple remix of byteborg's old Prusa flag, tweaked until it fits neatly in the new effector. Attach to the mounting point on the effector using a 2mm self-tapping screw.

Printer:

Micromake Kossel XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This is a very small print, so be wary. Use a skirt to ensure that printing starts cleanly.

I used black PLA, which is not ideal - as it is too reflective and will cause the optics to "bounce" back and not make a clean break (this is well documented in relation to other flags).

To avoid this, you can paint the PLA with something non-reflective (black paint, or in my case, black liquid electrical tape since that was lying around). Or use ABS.

OpenForge 2.0

Stone floors leaving your feet cold in the morning? Now your scenes can have wooden ones.

This is the first time I've designed a set of tiles entirely in blender. I've been trying to learn more techniques that will get me into organic designs. Special shout out to JenniferG for nudging me towards the techniques I used to make the timbers for this.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter

I needed to dig some cables in the ground and had that allready before, but from time to time the boxes i bought got water inside and the result was that my fuse felt out.

So I designed this small box where you can solder your cable inside and take easy buyable 2k Epoxy to put it and screw the lid on, Waterproof and no issue anymore, the wholes on the side you can drill on the size you need.

I printed it 100% infill, you don't need any support.

2k Epoxy you get everywhere in every home depot shop.

it uses around 12.5 mg of it to fill completely, the screws are 2.5" x 12

There is as well a double sized one under the following Link, for that you need 25mg of Epoxy 2k to fill out.

The picture attached is the bigger one as the small one didn't fit my big cables, one side was a 5.5 mm cable and on the other side it was 7.5 mm. That size of cables need the bigger one...

comments.text: this is a curious concept indeed, but I’m curious to the motive behind this. the scanner would not recreate the particles individually, nor would it show any kind of animation. the end result would inevitably be a smooth faced conical shape, and depending on the method used to pour the sand, trails emanating from the top formed from the rolling of grains down the slopes. I think you would get better results using Blender and render a physics based engine for particle simulation.

Mission Update - 160826

Several attempts to build a tracking system for the GaliPi Telescope failed due to high costs of building a rigid structure that allows tracking stars smoothly. I think the best solution is to actually purchase a Goto-mount for the telescope.

Mission Update - 160614

Finally I managed to run the first test with both cameras at the same time. Cam01 has a wide viewing angle and is used to aim for the particular objecct. Cam02 has a high magnification.

The test was very promising as you can see in the picture.

Release 0.1 - 160530

GaliPi is a project that aims to use Raspberry Pi Microcomputers to both control a Telecope and to take pictures of the night-sky. Many GaliPi telescopes can operate in a network and observe the same stellar object from different locations. Results are stored and shared.

The project was inspired by the Pikon project: https://pikonic.com/

Part 1 of the project focuses on getting good pictures. - In Progress

Part 2 focuses on targeting and tracking astronomical objects. - Q3.2016

Part 3 focuses on setting up a network of GaliPi telescopes. - 2017

Updates via Twitter > #GaliPi

Help wanted! If you want to participate in this project, please write an email: [email protected]

Blog: https://mytelescopeblog.wordpress.com
Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/galipi_astro
Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCoPGlrb8ny5pjF1T5WZha3A
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/GaliPiTelescope/

Moon example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8x9rRDL_pD4

Jupiter example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hzEicUOMZKY

Mission Goal

GaliPi is a digital telescope that captures images of the night sky with Raspberry Pi computers. The telescope operates autonomously and saves its observation results as digital images. Many GaliPi telescopes can operate in a network and observe the same stellar object from different locations. The results of such surveys are stored and shared in the cloud.

The main camera has a big magnification and captures a lot of light due to its newtonian setup. The wide field camera has a low magnification and captures big areas of the night sky.

Future versions of GaliPi should be able to automatically track stars and constellations.

The project is documented at: https://mytelescopeblog.wordpress.com

Parts List

1) 1x 3D Printed Parts (Drain Pipe Diameter 160mm)
2) 2x Raspberry (incl SD Card, WIFI and Power Supply)
3) 2x Raspberry Camera
4) 1x Lens for wide filed Raspberry Camera
5) Drain Pipe Diameter 160mm
6) Telescope Mirror-cell that fits into the Drain Pipe (Mine has a Diameter of 130mm)
7) Software: http://elinux.org/RPi-Cam-Web-Interface
8) 3x M5 Nylon Screws
9) 7x M5 Nylon Screw-nuts
10) 1x Equatorial mount for your telescope

description.text:
Extension caps that fit on a Rhoyxon hob's gas knobs. My hob is pretty old and should probably be replaced. The gas position indicator is faded and we had a near miss when one gas ring was left open overnight.

These knob extensions make it REALLY visible at a glance, if any gas ring is left in an open position (and by how much). Because of the curved heads, there's no clip/ clamp grip. Secure with a bit of blutack or double-sided tape.

These were printed in PLA and they withstand the heat from the nearby gas rings at full tilt.

description.text: I thought I would be able to push one of these (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9864) onto the smooth rod... I was wrong. It snapped. So I redesigned it for the same purpose in a retrofittable, push on style.

Press fit a 608ZZ bearing into the holder ringer, push onto the smooth rod and maneuver it into position.
Then tighten across the end (larger) through-hole with a M3 screw.
The other hole (closer to the throat) is intended for my fine adjustment end-stop mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:158872).

comments.text: Is the bore for the bearing supposed to be so tight? I'm pressing them in with a vice and they start making small cracks...

remixed_from.author: FunMove
remixed_from.title: FunMove Hand (Electronic Prosthetic Hand) - 1 Servo Motorization_ver.Sung

description.text:
This is the latest model of our prosthetic for trans-radial amputees. It as body actioned device for kids and grown ups. Instructions for priting and assembly are posted below. We'll keep updating this prosthetic, as well as continue uploading more of our designs.

This work was inspired by the Unlimbited Arm team with their thermoforming technique, the Funmove forearm system, GiveMeFive's flexy arm, Christian Silva's works, and the always amazing flexyhand by GyrobotUK

https://www.generosity.com/community-fundraising/po-3d-printing-prosthetics-with-attitude
Visit our crowdunding page for more info

Pasos para el armado de un ArmPO:

  • Termoformar el L_triceps y la L_base del antebrazo según el muñón del usuario.

  • Hacer las perforaciones correspondientes en la muñeca de LH_HandEX-ArmPO usando L_base termoformada como guia. Las perforaciones servirán para colocar los Pins y juntar la LH_HandEX-ArmPO y el antebrazo.

  • Ensamblar LH_HandEX-ArmPO (la palma)

  • Colocar los hilos a LH_HandEX-ArmPO

  • Unir L_base termoformada y L_triceps usando los Flexible ring.

  • Colocar los hilos al antebrazo.

  • Unir la LH_HandEX-ArmPO y el antebrazo usando los Pins y pegandolos.

  • Tensionar los hilos con los Tensioners. Usar un Tensioners para el pulgar y el otro para los demás dedos

  • Termoformar el Cover y unir el antebrazo con los Flexible ring.
Configuraciones de impresión
Las siguientes piezas son impresas con una impresora RepRap Prusa i3 con volumen de impresión de 230x400x250 mm

L_base y L_triceps:
La impresión se divide en dos partes porque tienen que ser impresas en dos porcentajes de relleno. Esta división de impresión radica en que estas piezas poseen diferentes puntos de esfuerzo. Este proceso de impresión dividida con dos configuraciones es posible con Simplify3D. Otros slicers tendran procesos diferentes de trabajo.

  • Primera parte:
    se imprime hasta 2 mm de altura con 20% de relleno(tipo rejilla), con ángulos de 90 y 0. Con una velocidad de impresión de 45 mm/s (dependiendo de la impresora)

  • Segunda parte:
    se comienza a imprimir a 2 mm de la altura y con un relleno(tipo rejilla) del 70% con ángulos de 90 y 0.Con una velocidad de impresión de 30 mm/s. La baja velocidad se debe a que la impresión es muy angosta, para prevenir problemas de deformación y cooling, y para mejorar la calidad de impresion.

Cover:
Se imprime con 20% de relleno (tipo rejilla), con ángulos de 90 y 0. Con una velocidad de impresión de 45 mm/s (dependiendo de la impresora).

Las siguientes piezas son impresas con una impresora RepRap Prusa i3 o FlashForge Creator Dual. Estas permiten imprimir PLA y filamento flexible.

Pins y Tensioners:
Se imprime con 70% de relleno (tipo rejilla), con ángulos de 90 y 0. Con una velocidad de impresión de 30 mm/s.

Las siguientes piezas son impresas con filamento flexible.

Flexible ring
Se imprime con 70% de relleno (tipo rejilla), con ángulos de 90 y 0. Con una velocidad de impresión de 30 mm/s.(esta velocidad depende del tipo de flexible y el tipo de impresora usada)

El resto de las partes son impresas con las configuraciones recomendas para una Flexyhand estándar

ArmPo Assembly instrucions

  • Thermoform L_triceps and L_base of the forearm according to the size of the users limb.

  • Make perforations corresponding to the wrist of LH_HandEX-ArmPO using the thermoformed L_base as a guide. The perforations are used for the Pins and to fix the LH_HandEX-ArmPO to the forearm

  • Standard flexy hand assembly for LH_HandEX-ArmPO

  • Standard flexy hand stringing for LH_HandEX-ArmPO

  • Fix the thermoformed L_base to L_triceps using the Flexible rings

  • String through the forearm.

  • Bind the LH_HandEX-ArmPO to the forearm using the Pins and the glueing them together

  • Tense the strings using the Tensioners. Use one Tensioner for the thumb and the other one for the remaining fingers

  • Thermoform the Cover and fix it to the forearm with the Flexible rings
Optimal print settings
The following pieces were printed with a RepRap Prusa I3 with a building volume of 230x400x250 mm^3

L_base and L_triceps
The print is divided in two parts because they require two different infill settings.This is due to the different strenghts needed in different parts of the piece, as well as cooling problems when printing a small cylinder. Note this is only possible with Simplify3D's slicer right now.

  • Part 1
    Layer height: 0,2mm
    Infill: Grid 20% with 90 and 0 Degrees angles.
    Speed: 45 mm/s
  • Part 2
    Layer height: 0,2 mm
    Infill: Grid 70% with 90 and 0 Degrees angles.
    Speed: 30 mm/s (slow printing speed to increase piece quality)

Cover:
Layer height: 0,2 mm
Infill: Grid 20% with 90 and 0 Degrees angles.
Speed: 45 mm/s (slow printing speed to increase piece quality)

The following pieces are printed with the RepRap Prusa I3 or Flashforge Creator Pro. These printers let you print with PLA and Flexible PTU

Pins and Tensioners
Layer height: 0,2 mm
Infill: Grid 70% with 90 and 0 Degrees angles.
Speed: 30 mm/s

The following pieces are printed in flexible filament

Flexible rings
Layer height: 0,2 mm
Infill: Grid 70% with 90 and 0 Degrees angles.
Speed: 30 mm/s (slow printing speed to increase piece quality)

The remaining pieces are printed with the recommended settings for a stardard FlexyHand
